citations.narrative:
During a paid public animal encounter session in October 2024, a child was bitten on their upper arm by the 5-month-old
female ring-tailed lemur “Zoey”. The lemur was under direct control of the handler during the interaction by use of a
lightweight leash that is attached around the animal’s abdomen. Prior to animal encounters, animal handlers inform
patrons to only pet the lemur on its back. The facility handler present at the time of the interaction reported that the
lemur’s tail had been pulled which could have contributed to the negative interaction. During public exhibition, any animal
must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with sufficient safeguards as to assure
the safety of animals and the public.
The facility instituted corrective action prior to this inspection on 11/27/2027 by moving “Zoey” to a non-contact exhibit and
an alternate ring-tailed lemur with a more amenable temperament is now used for animal encounters.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
